Module nl.naturalis.common
Package nl.naturalis.common.collection

Interface TypeMap<V>

Type Parameters:
V - The type of the values in the Map
All Superinterfaces:
Map<Class<?>,V>
All Known Implementing Classes:
LinkedTypeGraph, TypeGraph, TypeHashMap
public sealed interface TypeMap<V> extends Map<Class<?>,V>
A TypeMap is used to map Java types to values or actions (in the form of lambdas). Its main feature is that if a type, requested via get or containsKey, is not present in the map, but one of its supertypes is, then it will return the value associated with the supertype. The requested type's class hierarchy takes precedence over its interface hierarchy.

A TypeMap is not modifiable. All map-altering methods throw an UnsupportedOperationException. Map.getOrDefault(Object, Object) will also throw an UnsupportedOperationException as it sidesteps the TypeMap paradigm. Neither keys nor values are allowed to be null. If the map contains Object.class, it is guaranteed to always return a non-null value. Note that this is, in fact, a deviation from Java's type hierarchy since primitive types do not extend Object.class. However, the point of the TypeMap interface is to provide natural default values for groups of types through a common ancestor, and Object.class is the obvious candidate for delivering the ultimate, last-resort, fall-back value.

Autoboxing

A TypeMap can be configured to "autobox" the types requested by the client. For example, if the client makes a request for double.class, but the map only contains an entry for Double.class, then the value associated with Double.class is returned. If there is no entry for Double.class either, but there is one for Number.class, then the value associated with Number.class is returned. Thus, with autoboxing enabled, you need (and should) only add the primitive wrapper types to the map, unless you want the primitive type to be associated with a different value than the wrapper type.
